Title: Why isn't an infinite direct product of copies of $\Bbb Z$ a free module?
Content: Why isn't an infinite direct product of copies of $\Bbb Z$ a free module? Actually I was asked to show that it's not projective, but as $\Bbb{Z}$ is a PID, so it suffices to show it's not free. I am stuck here. I saw some questions in SE, but there is no satisfactory answer at all.
AcceptedAnswer: This failure of freeness is a non-trivial result.  One way to prove it is to begin with a lemma: If $F$ is a free abelian group and $C$ is a countable subgroup, then the quotient $F/C$  is the direct sum of a countable group and a free group.  (I'm omitting "abelian" because I'm lazy and all groups here will be abelian.)  [Proof of lemma: Fix a basis $B$ for $F$, let $B_0$ be the countable subset consisting of the basis elements that occur when you expand elements of $C$ in terms of your basis $B$.  Then $F$ is the direct sum of $F_0$ freely generated by $B_0$ and $F_1$ freely generated by $B-B_0$.  As $C\subseteq F_0$, it follows that $F/C$ is the direct sum of the countable group $F_0/C$ and the free group $F_1$.] As a corollary, under the hypotheses of the lemma, any divisible subgroup of $F/C$ must be included in the countable summand and must therefore be countable. Now suppose the direct product $P$ of countably infinitely many copies of $\mathbb Z$ were free.  The elements of $P$ are the all of the infinite sequences of integers.  Let $C$ be the subgroup of $P$ consisting of those sequences that have non-zero entries in only finitely many positions.  Then $C$ is countable, so the divisible part of $P/C$ would have to be countable.  But this divisible part contains the cosets (in $P/C$) of all the sequences (in $P$) of the form $n\mapsto n!\cdot a_n$ for arbitrary sequences of integers $(a_n)$.  So the divisible part of $P/C$ has the cardinality of the continuum. This contradiction shows that $P$ is not free. If your question was not only about $P$ but also about products of uncountably many copies of $\mathbb Z$, notice that such a product contains a copy of $P$, so you're done if you know that subgroups of free (abelian) groups are free.  If you don't know that, just re-run the argument in the preceding paragraph within a copy of $P$ inside your bigger product. By the way, a theorem of Specker shows that $P$ is not only not free but very far from free.  Since $P$ has cardinality $2^{\aleph_0}$, if it were free any basis for it would also have cardinality $2^{\aleph_0}$, so there would be $2^{2^{\aleph_0}}$ homomorphisms from $P$ to $\mathbb Z$ (because you could choose the images of the $2^{\aleph_0}$ basis elements arbitrarily).  Specker showed that there are only countably many homomorphisms $P\to\mathbb Z$, namely the $\mathbb Z$-linear combinations of the projections.

But if ∏ℤ were free with basis B, then Hom(∏ℤ, ℤ) would be isomorphic to the product of Hom(ℤ, ℤ)^B, which is the product of ℤ^B, which has cardinality at least 2^|B|. If B is uncountable, then 2^|B| is strictly larger than |⊕ℤ|, which is countable. Hence, contradiction. Therefore, ∏ℤ cannot be free.

proof strategy planner:
Assumption:
Assumption 1: ℤ is a PID
Assumption 2: The module in question is an infinite direct product of copies of ℤ (∏_{ℕ} ℤ)
Problem:
Prove that Free ℤ-modules are isomorphic to direct sums of copies of ℤ with uniquely defined ranks.
Proof sketch: 
Step 1) Define a free ℤ-module F as a module with a basis B (a linearly independent generating set over ℤ).
Step 2) Since ℤ is a PID, use the fact that submodules of free modules over PIDs are free.
Step 3) Construct a homomorphism φ: ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ → F by sending the standard basis element e_b to b. This is well-defined and surjective since B generates F.
Step 4) Show φ is injective: If φ(∑ n_b e_b) = 0, then ∑ n_b b = 0. By linear independence of B, all n_b = 0.
Step 5) Thus φ is an isomorphism, proving F ≅ ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ.
Step 6) For uniqueness of rank: Suppose F ≅ ⊕_{I} ℤ ≅ ⊕_{J} ℤ. Consider F/2F ≅ ⊕_{I} ℤ/2ℤ ≅ ⊕_{J} ℤ/2ℤ as vector spaces over ℤ/2ℤ.
Step 7) The dimension of F/2F over ℤ/2ℤ is |I| = |J|, proving the cardinalities are equal.
Step 8) Note: The assumption about ∏_{ℕ} ℤ shows that not every ℤ-module is free - this infinite product is NOT free over ℤ (Baer-Specker group).
mathematician and proof writer:
Assumption:
Assumption 1: ℤ is a PID
Assumption 2: The module in question is an infinite direct product of copies of ℤ (∏_{ℕ} ℤ)
Problem:
Prove that Free ℤ-modules are isomorphic to direct sums of copies of ℤ with uniquely defined ranks.
Let F be a free ℤ-module. By definition, F has a basis B, which is a subset of F such that:
1. B generates F (every element of F can be written as a finite ℤ-linear combination of elements of B)
2. B is linearly independent over ℤ (if ∑_{b∈B} n_b b = 0 with n_b ∈ ℤ and only finitely many n_b nonzero, then all n_b = 0)

Since ℤ is a PID (Principal Ideal Domain), we can use the following standard theorem from module theory: Over a PID, every submodule of a free module is free. However, for our immediate purpose, we don't need this theorem directly; we only need to construct the isomorphism.

Step 1: Construction of the isomorphism
Define a homomorphism φ: ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ → F as follows:
For each b ∈ B, let e_b be the standard basis element of the direct sum ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ, which has 1 in the b-coordinate and 0 elsewhere. Define φ(e_b) = b.
Extend φ ℤ-linearly: For any element ∑_{b∈B} n_b e_b ∈ ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ (with only finitely many n_b nonzero), define φ(∑_{b∈B} n_b e_b) = ∑_{b∈B} n_b b.

Step 2: φ is well-defined
Since any element of ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ has only finitely many nonzero coordinates, the sum ∑_{b∈B} n_b b is a finite sum in F, hence well-defined.

Step 3: φ is a ℤ-module homomorphism
For any x = ∑ n_b e_b and y = ∑ m_b e_b in ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ and any r ∈ ℤ:
φ(x + y) = φ(∑ (n_b + m_b) e_b) = ∑ (n_b + m_b) b = ∑ n_b b + ∑ m_b b = φ(x) + φ(y)
φ(rx) = φ(∑ (rn_b) e_b) = ∑ (rn_b) b = r∑ n_b b = rφ(x)

Step 4: φ is surjective
Since B generates F, every element f ∈ F can be written as f = ∑_{b∈B} n_b b for some n_b ∈ ℤ (with only finitely many nonzero). Then f = φ(∑_{b∈B} n_b e_b), so φ is surjective.

Step 5: φ is injective
Suppose φ(∑_{b∈B} n_b e_b) = 0. Then ∑_{b∈B} n_b b = 0 in F. By linear independence of B, all coefficients n_b must be 0. Hence ∑_{b∈B} n_b e_b = 0, so φ is injective.

Step 6: φ is an isomorphism
Since φ is a bijective ℤ-module homomorphism, it is an isomorphism. Therefore, F ≅ ⊕_{b∈B} ℤ.

Step 7: Uniqueness of rank
Suppose F is isomorphic to two direct sums: F ≅ ⊕_{I} ℤ ≅ ⊕_{J} ℤ, where I and J are index sets. We need to show |I| = |J|.

Consider the quotient module F/2F, where 2F = {2f : f ∈ F}. Since 2ℤ is an ideal of ℤ, 2F is a submodule of F.

Using the isomorphisms:
F/2F ≅ (⊕_{I} ℤ)/(⊕_{I} 2ℤ) ≅ ⊕_{I} (ℤ/2ℤ)
Similarly, F/2F ≅ ⊕_{J} (ℤ/2ℤ)

Now, ℤ/2ℤ is a field (of characteristic 2), so ⊕_{I} (ℤ/2ℤ) and ⊕_{J} (ℤ/2ℤ) are vector spaces over ℤ/2ℤ.

The dimension of ⊕_{I} (ℤ/2ℤ) as a ℤ/2ℤ-vector space is |I| (the cardinality of I), since the images of the standard basis elements form a basis.
Similarly, the dimension of ⊕_{J} (ℤ/2ℤ) is |J|.

Since these vector spaces are isomorphic (both isomorphic to F/2F), they have the same dimension. Therefore, |I| = |J|.

Step 8: Conclusion
We have shown that any free ℤ-module F is isomorphic to a direct sum ⊕_{B} ℤ, where B is any basis of F, and the cardinality |B| (called the rank of F) is uniquely determined by F (independent of the choice of basis).

Note: The assumption about ∏_{ℕ} ℤ (the infinite direct product of copies of ℤ) serves as an important example: while free ℤ-modules are direct sums of copies of ℤ, the module ∏_{ℕ} ℤ is NOT free over ℤ. This is known as the Baer-Specker group theorem. The existence of such non-free modules over ℤ (a PID) shows that not every ℤ-module is free, making the characterization of free modules particularly significant.
